Knowledge Point: Further, the V2 of an SVC does not appear with TMA marking, since it acquires its TMA specifications from the V1. Only the V1 is marked for tense\is{tense}, mood, and aspect. Hence, the second translation of \REF{ex:key:1542} as a motion-direction SVC is rejected. Instead, the construction may only be interpreted as involving a depictive secondary predicate (cf. \sectref{sec:11.3.2}). The inability to be independently marked for TMA also distinguishes SVCs from the verbal complements of aspectual and modal auxiliaries, some of which may be preceded by the imperfective aspect marker as well (cf. \sectref{sec:10.5.3}).
Content 1: \gll Yu \textbf{de} kɛ́r=an \textbf{de} gó hospital. | \gls 2SG IPFV carry=3SG.OBJ NEG go hospital | \glt ‘You’re carrying him while going to the hospital.’

Knowledge Point: The goal of the motion may be expressed as an object of the V2 motion verb as in \REF{ex:key:1543} above. The goal may also be instantiated in a prepositional phrase introduced by na ‘\textsc{loc}’ \REF{ex:key:1544}. Motion{\fff}-direction SVCs featuring a transitive V1 can involve a “switch-function{\fff}” (pro)noun (\citealt[14–15]{Aikhenvald2006}), in which case the object =an ‘\textsc{3sg.obj}’ of the V1 kɛ́r ‘carry’ may be analysed as the subject{\fff} of the V2 gó ‘go’ in the following example:
Content 1: \gll E sé “mɔ́mi mɔ́mi, yu nó de sí dán mán wé e \textbf{rɔ́n} \textbf{gó} abuela in rúm?” | \gls 3SG.SBJ QUOT mum mum 2SG NEG IPFV see that man SUB 3SG.SBJ run go grandmother 3SG.POSS room | \glt ‘He said “mum, mum, don’t you see that man who ran into grandmother’s room?”’
Content 2: \gll A kɛ́r=\textbf{an} gó na comedor. | \gls 1SG.SBJ carry=3SG.OBJ go LOC dining-room | \glt ‘I carried him to the dining-room.’

Knowledge Point: A string of two verbs may be followed by additional serial verbs. Example \REF{ex:key:1545} illustrates multiple serialisation{\fff} with the verb string kɛ́r-gó-wáka ‘carry-go-walk’. The construction is an overlap of a motion-direction SVC (kɛ́r-gó) and a motion-action SVC (gó-wáka):
Content 1: \gll Di bíg wán, a bin de \textbf{kɛ́r}=an \textbf{gó} \textbf{wáka} na nɛ́t wet Tokobé. | \gls DEF big one 1SG.SBJ PST IPFV carry=3SG.OBJ go walk LOC night with NAME | \glt ‘As for the big one, I was carrying it off travelling by night with Tokobé.’

Knowledge Point: The V2 kán ‘come’ expresses motion towards a ground \REF{ex:key:1546}. Strings involving the verb kɔmɔ́t ‘go out’ as the V2 express evacuation, i.e. motion out of a ground \REF{ex:key:1547}. Note the presence of the prepositions fɔ ‘\textsc{prep’}\is{associative preposition} and na ‘\textsc{loc’}\is{general} which mark goal and source,\index{} respectively:
Content 1: \gll A tínk sé e gɛ́t treinta y ocho años náw wé e dɔ́n de \textbf{gó} \textbf{rích} cuarenta. | \gls 1SG.SBJ think QUOT 3SG.SBJ get thirty and eight years now SUB 3SG.SBJ PRF IPFV go reach forty | \glt ‘I think that he’s thirty-eight years old now and is already going towards forty.’
Content 2: \gll E kán \textbf{rɔ́n} \textbf{kɔmɔ́t} \textbf{na} kɔ́ntri, (...) | \gls 3SG.SBJ PFV run go.out LOC country (...) | \glt ‘She fled from the [her] home town, (...)’

Knowledge Point: The notion of ‘movement up to’ is formed with the verb rích ‘arrive’ in the V2 position as in \REF{ex:key:1548}. This construction is, however, rare:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The situation expressed by motion-direction SVCs is more often expressed in non-serial structures featuring prepositional phrases\is{prepositional phrases} as in \REF{ex:key:1549}. In these constructions, context and common sense disambiguate the potentially locative (i.e. ‘in the pharmacy’) and goal (‘to the pharmacy’) meanings of the PP introduced by the general locative preposition\is{general} na ‘\textsc{loc}’:
Content 1: \gll Dɛn rɔ́n \textbf{na} \textbf{farmacia}, receta de mɛ́rɛsin. | \gls 3PL run LOC pharmacy prescription of medicine | \glt ‘They ran to the pharmacy, (to get a) prescription for medicine.’

Knowledge Point: The construction may involve another motion verb as V2 \REF{ex:key:1550}, or any other dynamic verb \REF{ex:key:1551}. Motion-action SVCs are only attested with a dynamic V2:
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll \'{A}pás tumɔ́ro a go \textbf{gó} \textbf{sí} mi mamá. | \gls after tomorrow 1SG.SBJ POT go see 1SG.POSS mother | \glt ‘After tomorrow, I will go see my mother.’

Knowledge Point: Below follow motion-action SVCs involving the minor verb kán ‘come’ as the V1. Like gó{}-SVCs, kán{}-SVCs are encountered with \REF{ex:key:1552} and without \REF{ex:key:1553} resumptive\is{resumptive pronouns} subject\is{subjects} marking with the V2:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Yu} kán \textbf{yu} púl=an. | \gls 2SG come 2SG remove=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘You came and removed it.’
Content 2: \gll Na ín \textbf{e} de kán púl mí dán torí. | \gls FOC 3SG.INDP 3SG.SBJ IPFV come remove 1SG.INDP that story | \glt ‘That’s when she was coming to tell me that story.’

Knowledge Point: SVCs involving the use of kán as a verb in a motion-action SVC like \REF{ex:key:1553} need to be distinguished from the use of kán as a narrative perfective\is{perfective aspect} aspect marker in a sentence like \REF{ex:key:1554}. There are two ways of making the distinction. Firstly, in \REF{ex:key:1553}, the lexical verb kán ‘come’ may be marked by TMA markers like any other Pichi verb. On the contrary, the narrative perfective marker kán ‘\textsc{pfv}’ is subject to co-occurrence restrictions. For example, the TMA marker sequence *de kán ‘\textsc{ipfv} \textsc{pfv}’ in \REF{ex:key:1553} above would be ungrammatical in \REF{ex:key:1554}.\is{aspect}
Content 1: \gll Na ín \textbf{e} de kán púl mí dán torí. | \gls FOC 3SG.INDP 3SG.SBJ IPFV come remove 1SG.INDP that story | \glt ‘That’s when she was coming to tell me that story.’
Content 2: \gll Na ín e \textbf{kán} \textbf{vɛ́ks}, e \textbf{kán} \textbf{gó}. | \gls FOC 3SG.INDP 3SG.SBJ PFV be.angry 3SG.SBJ PFV go | \glt ‘That’s why he got angry, (and) he left.’
Content 3: \gll Na ín \textbf{e} de kán púl mí dán torí. | \gls FOC 3SG.INDP 3SG.SBJ IPFV come remove 1SG.INDP that story | \glt ‘That’s when she was coming to tell me that story.’
Content 4: \gll Na ín \textbf{e} de kán púl mí dán torí. | \gls FOC 3SG.INDP 3SG.SBJ IPFV come remove 1SG.INDP that story | \glt ‘That’s when she was coming to tell me that story.’
Content 5: \gll Na ín e \textbf{kán} \textbf{vɛ́ks}, e \textbf{kán} \textbf{gó}. | \gls FOC 3SG.INDP 3SG.SBJ PFV be.angry 3SG.SBJ PFV go | \glt ‘That’s why he got angry, (and) he left.’

Knowledge Point: Secondly, speakers may employ resumptive subject\is{subjects} marking with the V2 in sentences like \REF{ex:key:1552} above in order to avoid the potential ambiguity between a motion-action SVC and a verb marked for narrative perfective aspect (i.e. yu kán púl=an ‘\textsc{2sg} come remove=\textsc{3sg.obj}’ = ‘(then) you removed it)’. The same strategy is employed in \REF{ex:key:1555} below. In both examples, the bare lexical verb kán ‘come’ is likely to be interpreted as the narrative perfective marker kán ‘\textsc{pfv’} if the sequence were not interrupted by the personal pronoun yu ‘\textsc{2sg}’. That said, these two uses of kán are often very similar and appear to be diachronically related:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Yu} kán \textbf{yu} púl=an. | \gls 2SG come 2SG remove=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘You came and removed it.’
Content 2: \gll Porque if yu mék, yu sí dán polvo, e de pút=an ínsay, \textbf{yu} \textbf{kán} \textbf{yu} \textbf{dríng}, (...) | \gls because if 2SG make 2SG see that powder 3SG.SBJ IPFV put=3SG.OBJ inside 2SG come 2SG drink (...) | \glt ‘Because if you make, you see that powder, he’s putting it inside, you come and drink (...)’

Knowledge Point: Motion-action SVCs frequently involve the use of resumptive\is{resumptive `go'} gó and kán. \is{resumptive `kan'}In \REF{ex:key:1556}, the verb string is interrupted by the adverbial phrase na peluquería ‘to the hairdresser’s’, after which we find a resumptive gó. Example \REF{ex:key:1557} features resumptive kán after the adverbial phrase wán dé ‘one day’:
Content 1: \gll Ɛf yu wánt bába, yu wánt \textbf{gó} na peluquería \textbf{gó} \textbf{kɔ́t} yu hía. | \gls if 2SG want cut.hair 2SG want go LOC hairdresser’s go cut 2SG hair | \glt ‘If you want to have a hair-cut, you want to go cut your hair at the hairdresser’s.’
Content 2: \gll Dán mán fít \textbf{kán} wán dé \textbf{kán} \textbf{ték} yú sé “kán wi gó”, (...) | \gls that man can come one day come take 2SG.INDP QUOT come 1PL go (...) | \glt ‘That man can come take you one day (and) say “let’s go” (...)’

Knowledge Point: A more literal motion meaning may give way to a purposive meaning. In \REF{ex:key:1558}, movement to the speakers hometown has already occurred before the motion-action SVC a gó bɔ́n ‘I went to give birth’ follows. There is no prosodic juncture between the two clauses:
Content 1: \gll A \textbf{gó} fɔ kɔ́ntri a \textbf{gó} \textbf{bɔ́n}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ go PREP country 1SG.SBJ go give.birth | \glt ‘I went to my home town in order to give birth.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:key:1559}, the literal meaning of the V1 gó recedes further behind a purposive sense. In this example, we see how motion through space instantiated by kɛ́r ‘bring’, the motion metaphor of the purpose clause{\fff} introduced by fɔ ‘\textsc{prep}’, and the motion/purpose reading of gó itself harmonise:
Content 1: \gll Dɛn kán \textbf{kɛ́r} mí na Madrid \textbf{fɔ} mék dɛn \textbf{gó} opera mí. | \gls 3PL PFV carry 1SG.INDP LOC PLACE PREP SBJV 3PL go operate 1SG.INDP | \glt ‘They took me to Madrid in order to go and operate me.’

Knowledge Point: The motion-action SVC in \REF{ex:key:1560} does not involve directed motion through space either. The SVC a gó a púl di trɔsis ‘I (went and) removed the trousers’ involves no motion other than removing the pair of trousers:
Content 1: \gll A púl in camiseta, a pút=an pantáp béd, \textbf{a} \textbf{gó} \textbf{a} \textbf{púl} \textbf{di} \textbf{trɔsis} a híb=an ínsay di bañera. | \gls 1SG.SBJ remove 3SG.POSS singlet 1SG.SBJ put=3SG.OBJ top bed 1SG.SBJ go 1SG.SBJ remove DEF trousers 1SG.SBJ throw=3SG.OBJ inside DEF bath.tub | \glt ‘I removed his singlet, I put him on the bed, I (went and) removed his trousers, I heaved him into the bath tub.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:key:1560} also points towards a difference in meaning that may arise between motion-action serialisation without resumptive\is{resumptive pronouns} subject marking (cf. e.g. \ref{ex:key:1559} above) and motion-action SVCs, in which the V2 has an overt subject\is{subjects} pronoun (cf. e.g. \ref{ex:key:1560}). While the former type tends to extend metaphorically into the expression of purpose relations, the latter tends to focus the action designated by V2. Motion-action SVCs involving kán also lend themselves to less literal interpretations. Compare \REF{ex:key:1555} above, where the V1 kán also focuses the following V2 dríng ‘drink’.\is{motion-action SVCs}
Content 1: \gll A púl in camiseta, a pút=an pantáp béd, \textbf{a} \textbf{gó} \textbf{a} \textbf{púl} \textbf{di} \textbf{trɔsis} a híb=an ínsay di bañera. | \gls 1SG.SBJ remove 3SG.POSS singlet 1SG.SBJ put=3SG.OBJ top bed 1SG.SBJ go 1SG.SBJ remove DEF trousers 1SG.SBJ throw=3SG.OBJ inside DEF bath.tub | \glt ‘I removed his singlet, I put him on the bed, I (went and) removed his trousers, I heaved him into the bath tub.’
Content 2: \gll Dɛn kán \textbf{kɛ́r} mí na Madrid \textbf{fɔ} mék dɛn \textbf{gó} opera mí. | \gls 3PL PFV carry 1SG.INDP LOC PLACE PREP SBJV 3PL go operate 1SG.INDP | \glt ‘They took me to Madrid in order to go and operate me.’
Content 3: \gll A púl in camiseta, a pút=an pantáp béd, \textbf{a} \textbf{gó} \textbf{a} \textbf{púl} \textbf{di} \textbf{trɔsis} a híb=an ínsay di bañera. | \gls 1SG.SBJ remove 3SG.POSS singlet 1SG.SBJ put=3SG.OBJ top bed 1SG.SBJ go 1SG.SBJ remove DEF trousers 1SG.SBJ throw=3SG.OBJ inside DEF bath.tub | \glt ‘I removed his singlet, I put him on the bed, I (went and) removed his trousers, I heaved him into the bath tub.’
Content 4: \gll Porque if yu mék, yu sí dán polvo, e de pút=an ínsay, \textbf{yu} \textbf{kán} \textbf{yu} \textbf{dríng}, (...) | \gls because if 2SG make 2SG see that powder 3SG.SBJ IPFV put=3SG.OBJ inside 2SG come 2SG drink (...) | \glt ‘Because if you make, you see that powder, he’s putting it inside, you come and drink (...)’

Knowledge Point: In the first type, the object of the V1 ték ‘take’ is the instrument\is{instrument SVC}\index{} or means used for performing V2. Compare wán blák lapá ‘a black cloth’ in \REF{ex:key:1561}. The instrument may also be an abstract noun like páwa ‘power’ \REF{ex:key:1562} or papá gɔ́d ‘God’ in the idiom in \REF{ex:key:1563}:
Content 1: \gll E kin dé lɛk sé dɛn ték \textbf{wán} \textbf{blák} \textbf{lapá} dɛn kɔ́ba yú. | \gls 3SG.SBJ HAB BE.LOC like QUOT 3PL take one black cloth 3PL cover 2SG.INDP | \glt ‘It is usually so that they cover you with a black cloth.’
Content 2: \gll Yu fít gó sé “bueno a ték \textbf{páwa} gó” (...) | \gls 2SG can go QUOT good 1SG.SBJ take power go (...) | \glt ‘You can go and say, “well, I leave by my own authority” (...)’
Content 3: \gll A ték \textbf{papá} \textbf{gɔ́d} bɛ́g=an. | \gls 1SG.SBJ take father God ask=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘I implored him in the name of God.’

Knowledge Point: Compare the alternative translations of \REF{ex:key:1564} and \REF{ex:key:1565}. Note the use of a resumptive\is{resumptive pronouns} object pronoun alone in the first example, and the use of both a resumptive object and subject pronoun in the second one:
Content 1: \gll A ték=\textbf{an} pút=\textbf{an} pantáp mi bɛlɛ́. | \gls 1SG.SBJ take=3SG.OBJ put=3SG.OBJ top 1SG.POSS belly | \glt ‘I (took him and) put him onto my belly.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Yu} ték di maíz \textbf{yu} hól=an. | \gls 2SG take DEF maize 2SG hold=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘You take the maize (and) you hold it.’

Knowledge Point: When the theme object of ték is human, it may also receive a comitative ‘together with’ interpretation. This occurs with the object di gɛ́l ‘the girl’ in the relative construction{\fff} in \REF{ex:key:1567}:
Content 1: \gll Porque e fíba sé \textbf{di} \textbf{gɛ́l} [wé e bin de \textbf{ték} \textbf{kɔmɔ́t}], e bin gɛ́t bɔkú bɔ́y dɛn. | \gls because 3SG.SBJ seem QUOT DEF girl SUB 3SG.SBJ PST IPFV take go.out 3SG.SBJ PST get much boy PL | \glt ‘Because it seems that the girl that he was going out with, she had many boyfriends.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:key:1567} above is also noteworthy because it shows what happens when the object of ték is relativised. The object di gɛ́l ‘the girl’ is placed in the head noun position, while the relativised position may remain empty, which leads to V1 and V2 occurring next to each other. Contiguity of ték and the V2 is also found when the object of ték is fronted in content questions{\fff}. Sentence \REF{ex:key:1568} features the questioned concrete noun plɛ́nk ‘board’ and \REF{ex:key:1569} the abstract noun stáyl ‘manner’:
Content 1: \gll Porque e fíba sé \textbf{di} \textbf{gɛ́l} [wé e bin de \textbf{ték} \textbf{kɔmɔ́t}], e bin gɛ́t bɔkú bɔ́y dɛn. | \gls because 3SG.SBJ seem QUOT DEF girl SUB 3SG.SBJ PST IPFV take go.out 3SG.SBJ PST get much boy PL | \glt ‘Because it seems that the girl that he was going out with, she had many boyfriends.’
Content 2: \gll \'{U}s=káyn plɛ́nk dɛn \textbf{ték} \textbf{bíl} di hós? | \gls Q=kind board 3PL take build DEF house | \glt ‘What kind of board did they build the house with?’
Content 3: \gll Na ús=káyn stáyl yu \textbf{ték} \textbf{kán} na yá? | \gls FOC Q=kind style 2SG take come LOC here | \glt ‘How did you come here.’

Knowledge Point: SVCs involving ték are less frequent than equivalent combinations of verbs and prepositions. A PP involving wet ‘with’ is more commonly employed to express the semantic role of instrument\index{} \REF{ex:key:1570}. Comitative ték{}-serialisations are even less common. Speakers usually resort to a PP introduced by the preposition wet ‘with’ as in \REF{ex:key:1575} further below:
Content 1: \gll Dɛn \textbf{bíl} di strít \textbf{wet} caterpillar. | \gls 3PL build DEF street with caterpillar | \glt ‘The street was built with a caterpillar.’
Content 2: \gll E gó \textbf{wet} in mamá? | \gls 3SG.SBJ go with 3SG.POSS mother | \glt ‘Did he go with his mother?’

Knowledge Point: The competition between the serial and prepositional strategies of participant-marking is manifest in the rather exceptional sentences \REF{ex:key:1571} and \REF{ex:key:1572} elicited from two different speakers. Here, the questioning of the instrument noun produced redundant marking of the question phrase ús=káyn tín ‘\textsc{q}=kind thing’ = ‘\textsc{what’} with both a preposition and a ték{}-SVC. Non-interrogative double uses of this kind were not found, however:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Wet} ús=káyn tín dɛn \textbf{ték} \textbf{bíl} di hós? | \gls with Q=kind thing 3PL take build DEF house | \glt ‘(With) what did they build the house with?’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Wet} ús=káyn stík yu bin \textbf{ték} \textbf{bíl} di hós? | \gls with Q=kind wood 2SG PST take build DEF house | \glt ‘(With) what kind of wood did you build the house with?’

Knowledge Point: Once more, most speakers prefer to express accompaniment through non-serial alternatives. One possibility is the use of the verb jwɛ́n ‘join’, followed by the nominalised reference verb{\fff} as in \REF{ex:key:1574}. The most common means involves a comitative prepositional phrase introduced by wet ‘with’ \REF{ex:key:1575}:
Content 1: \gll A \textbf{jwɛ́n} Boyé \textbf{fɔ} \textbf{chɔ́p}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ join NAME PREP eat | \glt ‘I ate together with Boyé.’
Content 2: \gll E gó \textbf{wet} in mamá? | \gls 3SG.SBJ go with 3SG.POSS mother | \glt ‘Did he go with his mother?’

Knowledge Point: A final type of participant-introducing SVC is the comparative construction \is{comparative SVC}featuring the verb pás ‘(sur)pass’ \REF{ex:key:1576}. The object of pás is the standard of comparison. Comparative SVCs are covered in detail in section \sectref{sec:6.9.1}:
Content 1: \gll Lage de \textbf{tɔ́k} Bubɛ \textbf{pás} mí. | \gls NAME IPFV talk Bube pass 1SG.INDP | \glt ‘Lage speaks Bube better than me.’

Knowledge Point: This type of SVC features a verb of immediate perception as a minor verb and V1. In the corpus, this construction is attested with sí ‘see’ and hía ‘hear’ as V1. The construction features a switch-function (pro)noun\is{switch-function (pro)nouns}. In \REF{ex:key:1577}, the object of sí ‘see’, i.e. sɔn wáyt pambɔ́d ‘a white bird’, functions as the notional subject\is{subjects} of the V2 kán ‘come’:
Content 1: \gll A \textbf{sí} sɔn wáyt pambɔ́d \textbf{de} \textbf{kán}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ see some white bird IPFV come | \glt ‘I saw a white bird coming.’

Knowledge Point: When the V2 in a complementation SVC is an inchoative-stative property item, the V2 may appear with an overt subject\is{subjects} e ‘\textsc{3sg.sbj}’, which is coreferential with the preceding object pronoun =an ‘\textsc{3sg.obj}’, as in the example below. Without the V2 subject, the property item fáyn would be interpreted as an adverbial modifier of sí ‘see’. This structure is now in fact identical to some of the depictive secondary predications covered in section \sectref{sec:11.3}, e.g. \REF{ex:key:1601}. Complementation structures are therefore not so clear-cut cases of SVCs, and it is debatable whether they should not be seen as “overlapping clauses” \citep{Ameka2006}, hence multiclausal structures.
Content 1: \gll Pero dɛn kán \textbf{dú} \textbf{mí} \textbf{a} de sté na Móka, dɛn kán dú mí na Móka. | \gls but 3PL PFV do 1SG.INDP 1SG.SBJ IPFV stay LOC PLACE 3PL PFV do 1SG.INDP LOC PLACE | \glt ‘But they did it to me while I was staying in Moka, they did it to me in Moka.’

Knowledge Point: Two verbs in the corpus appear as minor verbs in adverbial SVCs. In these structures the V1 provides a modification that is temporal in nature. The verb lás ‘be the last to, end up’ enters into an adverbial SVC as a minor verb \REF{ex:key:1580}. Proof for the verbal status of lás comes from \REF{ex:key:1581}: lás may not appear in the postverbal adverbial position. In contrast, the word fɔ́s ‘first’ which also expresses temporal meanings may, since it is an adverb \REF{ex:key:1582}:
Content 1: \gll \MakeUppercase{A} \textbf{lás} \textbf{chɔ́p}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ be.last eat | \glt ‘I was the last to eat/I ended up eating.’
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gll A wás \textbf{fɔ́s}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ wash first | \glt ‘I washed (myself) first.’

Knowledge Point: Many speakers instead prefer to express duration through a biclausal structure with co-referential subjects \REF{ex:key:1584} or an expletive subject to sté \REF{ex:key:1585}. The latter use is once more similar to secondary predication covered below in section \sectref{sec:11.3}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{A} \textbf{sté} wé \textbf{a} nɛ́va chɔ́p. | \gls 1SG.SBJ stay SUB 1SG.SBJ NEG.PRF eat | \glt ‘It’s been long since I haven’t eaten.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{E} nó \textbf{sté} a recibe di carta, di tín wé a bɛ́g. | \gls 3SG.SBJ NEG stay 1SG.SBJ receive DEF letter DEF thing SUB 1SG.SBJ ask.for | \glt ‘It wasn’t long and I received the letter, the thing I (had) asked for.’

Subsection: Secondary predication vs. serial verb constructions
Knowledge Point: Secondary predicates can be distinguished from SVCs on formal grounds. For one, the secondary predicate is connected to the primary predicate in a loose way, i.e. via adjunction. The secondary predicate can therefore be paraphrased by fuller clauses with sometimes only slight modifications to the sentence (cf. \ref{ex:key:1590}).
Content 1: \gll A lɛ́f di domɔ́t \textbf{ópin}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ leave DEF door be.open | \glt ‘I left the door open.’

Subsection: Secondary predication vs. serial verb constructions
Knowledge Point: Further, the V2 of an SVC acquires its TMA specification from the V1; the V2 may not be independently marked for tense\is{tense}, mood,\is{mood} and aspect (cf. \ref{ex:key:1542}). In contrast, depictive secondary predicates must be marked for simultaneity by imperfective aspect, either via factative TMA or via de ‘\textsc{ipfv’.} Compare the imperfective-marked secondary predicate chɔ́p ‘eat’ in this example: \is{aspect}
Content 1: \gll Yu \textbf{de} kɛ́r=an \textbf{de} gó hospital. | \gls 2SG IPFV carry=3SG.OBJ NEG go hospital | \glt ‘You’re carrying him while going to the hospital.’

Subsection: Secondary predication vs. serial verb constructions
Knowledge Point: Many secondary predicates in the data do not feature overt subjects either and in that, they resemble the V2s of SVCs like \REF{ex:key:1586} above. However, contrary to the SVC in \REF{ex:key:1586}, the notional subject of the secondary predicate may optionally be expressed. Secondary predicates may therefore be expanded into fuller clauses.
Content 1: \gll A kɛ́r=\textbf{an} gó na comedor. | \gls 1SG.SBJ carry=3SG.OBJ go LOC dining-room | \glt ‘I carried him to the dining-room.’
Content 2: \gll A kɛ́r=\textbf{an} gó na comedor. | \gls 1SG.SBJ carry=3SG.OBJ go LOC dining-room | \glt ‘I carried him to the dining-room.’

Knowledge Point: Some depictive secondary predications may alternatively be expressed through nominal depictives. One strategy involves the use of a prepositional phrase introduced by the multifunctional preposition wet ‘with’ (cf. also \ref{ex:key:888} and \ref{ex:key:885}–\ref{ex:key:886} in \sectref{sec:7.7.2}):
Content 1: \gll Di cubana húman de \textbf{wók} \textbf{lɛk} \textbf{dɔ́kta} na Malábo. | \gls DEF Cuban woman IPFV work like doctor LOC PLACE | \glt ‘The Cuban woman works as a doctor in Malabo.’
Content 2: \gll E pút di bɔ́tul pan di tébul \textbf{wet} \textbf{di} \textbf{mɔ́t} \textbf{dɔ́n}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ put DEF bottle pan DEF table with DEF mouth down | \glt ‘He put the bottle on the table upside-down.’
Content 3: \gll Pero mi mamá kán acepta di pikín \textbf{lɛk} \textbf{mi} \textbf{brɔ́da} \textbf{in} \textbf{pikín}. | \gls but 1SG.POSS mother PFV accept DEF child like 1SG brother 3SG.POSS child | \glt ‘But my mother accepted the child as my brother’s child.’

Knowledge Point: A common subject-oriented depictive construction in the data involves the expression of “associated posture” \citep{Enfield2002}: The secondary predicate denotes a situation that holds while the subject\is{subjects} assumes a posture denoted by the primary predicate. The secondary predicate is therefore both participant- (the subject) and event-oriented (the primary predicate). When associated posture verbs co-occur with a dynamic secondary predicate, temporal simultaneity is marked overtly by imperfective marking. This is the case in \REF{ex:key:1596} where the posture verb sidɔ́n ‘sit (down)’ is followed by the imperfective\is{imperfective aspect} marked dynamic verb chɔ́p ‘eat’: \is{aspect}
Content 1: \gll Yu pikín \textbf{sidɔ́n} \textbf{de} \textbf{chɔ́p} dɛn tú brɛ́d. | \gls 2SG child sit IPFV eat 3PL two bread | \glt ‘Your child was sitting there eating those two loaves of bread.’

Knowledge Point: The secondary predicate in an associated posture construction may also be another locative verb\is{locative verbs} that elaborates on the type of posture taken by the subject. In \REF{ex:key:1597}, the posture verb sidɔ́n ‘sit (down)’ is followed by the inchoative-stative locative verb ráwn ‘form a circle’. Since ráwn is not dynamic, the situation of temporal overlap is not marked by means of the imperfective aspect. It is rather marked by factative TMA, hence the bare verb (cf. \sectref{sec:6.1}). The use of a co-referential subject\is{subjects} pronoun with the V2 (the second dɛn ‘\textsc{3pl’} in the example) is the norm if the secondary predicate is not dynamic:
Content 1: \gll Dɛn \textbf{sidɔ́n} \textbf{dɛn} \textbf{ráwn} di fáya. | \gls 3PL sit 3PL surround DEF fire | \glt ‘They’re sitting around the fire.’ or ‘They sat down around the fire.’

Knowledge Point: The construction in \REF{ex:key:1600} features the locomotion verb wáka ‘walk’ as primary predicate and the idiomatic reflexive construction ópin in sɛ́f ‘(to) boast’ as secondary predicate. Note the presence of the resumptive subject{\fff} pronoun e ‘\textsc{3sg.sbj}’ in this example as well:
Content 1: \gll E nó gɛ́t mɔní, wétin e de \textbf{wáka} e de \textbf{ópin} in sɛ́f so? | \gls 3SG.SBJ NEG get money what 3SG.SBJ IPFV walk 3SG.SBJ IPFV open 3SG.POSS self like.that | \glt ‘He doesn’t have money, why does he go around boasting like that?’

Knowledge Point: Animacy provides additional cues to the meaning of constructions involving secondary predication. When the object of a transitive verb has an animate object as in \REF{ex:key:1601} (i.e. mí ‘\textsc{1sg.indp’),} the secondary predicate may be interpreted as either subject- or object-oriented. In such cases, the secondary predicate requires a subject pronoun in order to establish reference with either of the two participants:\is{adjuncts}
Content 1: \gll Pero dɛn kán \textbf{dú} \textbf{mí} \textbf{a} de sté na Móka, dɛn kán dú mí na Móka. | \gls but 3PL PFV do 1SG.INDP 1SG.SBJ IPFV stay LOC PLACE 3PL PFV do 1SG.INDP LOC PLACE | \glt ‘But they did it to me while I was staying in Moka, they did it to me in Moka.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:key:1602}, the verb of production pént ‘paint’ is followed by the patient\is{patient} object hós ‘house’ and the secondary predicate blák ‘black’. The secondary predicated is an object-oriented resultative adjunct that denotes the resultant state of the event denoted by the primary predicate:
Content 1: \gll E \textbf{pént} di hós \textbf{blák}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ paint DEF house black | \glt ‘He painted the house black.’

Knowledge Point: Sentence \REF{ex:key:1603} features the effected-object verb\is{} mék ‘make, prepare’ as a primary predicate. Note that the secondary predicate takes the subject\is{subjects} pronoun e ‘\textsc{3sg.sbj}’, which is co-referential with the primary predicate object café ‘coffee’. The overt subject pronoun is not necessary here because the resultative predicate is clearly object-oriented (unlike the primary predicate presented in \ref{ex:key:1588} above). I assume that an explicit subject pronoun is nevertheless employed because of the presence of the preverbal degree adverb tú ‘too (much)’. This makes the secondary predicate more complex and motivates the use of a finite resultative clause featuring an overt subject:
Content 1: \gll Dɛn \textbf{mék} di café \textbf{e} \textbf{tú} \textbf{swít}. | \gls 3PL make DEF coffee 3SG.SBJ too be.sweet | \glt ‘They prepared the coffee (it’s) too sweet.’
Content 2: \gll E mít \textbf{mí} \textbf{a} de kúk sɛ́f. | \gls 3SG.SBJ meet 1SG.INDP 1SG.SBJ IPFV cook EMP | \glt ‘He came across me while I was actually cooking.’

Knowledge Point: Resultatives may be paraphrased by employing a nominal strategy. The resultative secondary predicate in \REF{ex:key:1604}, i.e. the property item wɔwɔ́ ‘be ugly, messed up’ may be vaguely paraphrased via an NP in which it appears as a prenominal modifier to the generic noun stáyl ‘manner’ \REF{ex:key:1605}. The generic noun stáyl ‘manner’ is also used in modifications of manner (cf. e.g. \ref{ex:key:880} in \sectref{sec:7.7.2}) and in manner question words (cf. e.g. \ref{ex:key:629} in \sectref{sec:7.3.2}), hence in \REF{ex:key:1605}, it is ambiguous between a participant-oriented resultative reading and an event-oriented manner reading:
Content 1: \gll Dɛn \textbf{bíl} di ród \textbf{wɔwɔ́}. | \gls 3PL build DEF road be.ugly | \glt ‘They built the road (and it’s) shoddy.’
Content 2: \gll Dɛn \textbf{bíl}=an \textbf{wɔwɔ́} \textbf{stáyl}. | \gls 3PL build=3SG.OBJ ugly style | \glt ‘They built it (and it’s) shoddy.’ or ‘They built it shoddily.’
Content 3: \gll Dɛn tíf di mɔní \textbf{síkrit} \textbf{stáyl}. | \gls 3PL steal DEF money secret style | \glt ‘They stole the money secretly.’
Content 4: \gll Na \textbf{ús=káyn} \textbf{stáyl} yu ték kán na yá? | \gls FOC Q=kind style 2SG take come LOC here | \glt ‘By which means did you come here?’
Content 5: \gll Dɛn \textbf{bíl}=an \textbf{wɔwɔ́} \textbf{stáyl}. | \gls 3PL build=3SG.OBJ ugly style | \glt ‘They built it (and it’s) shoddy.’ or ‘They built it shoddily.’

Knowledge Point: The following example illustrates how the difference between clause chaining and the linkage of fully finite clauses may hinge on intonation when a series of dynamic verbs are marked for factative TMA.\is{resumptive pronouns} In \REF{ex:key:1612}, the verbs ték ‘take’, pé ‘pay’, kɔmɔ́t ‘go out’, rích ‘arrive’, and pé ‘pay’ are iconically ordered along the time axis and describe successive events. However, they are separated by pauses. Additionally, the last constituent of each clause bears continuative intonation\is{continuative intonation} (indicated by a comma), which alerts the hearer to the existence of a clausal boundary. For these reasons, \REF{ex:key:1612} does not involve clause chaining:
Content 1: \gll Lúk=an, di dé wé dís Paquita in papá bin kán \textbf{ték}=an, e \textbf{pé} avioneta \textbf{kɔmɔ́t} Alemania, \textbf{rích} na Douala, \textbf{pé} avioneta, e \textbf{kán} na yá só. | \gls look=3SG.OBJ DEF day SUB this NAME 3SG.POSS father PST come take=3SG.OBJ 3SG.SBJ pay small.aircraft go.out PLACE reach LOC PLACE pay small.aircraft 3SG.SBJ come LOC here like.that | \glt ‘Look at her, the day that Paquita’s father came to take her, he paid (a ticket for) a small plane, left Germany, got to Douala, paid (a ticket for) a small plane, (and) came here.’
Content 2: \gll Lúk=an, di dé wé dís Paquita in papá bin kán \textbf{ték}=an, e \textbf{pé} avioneta \textbf{kɔmɔ́t} Alemania, \textbf{rích} na Douala, \textbf{pé} avioneta, e \textbf{kán} na yá só. | \gls look=3SG.OBJ DEF day SUB this NAME 3SG.POSS father PST come take=3SG.OBJ 3SG.SBJ pay small.aircraft go.out PLACE reach LOC PLACE pay small.aircraft 3SG.SBJ come LOC here like.that | \glt ‘Look at her, the day that Paquita’s father came to take her, he paid (a ticket for) a small plane, left Germany, got to Douala, paid (a ticket for) a small plane, (and) came here.’
